title: James, a Case of Referred Pain from Costochondritis
clinical_history: James is a 45-year-old insurance broker who initially started experiencing discomfort in his chest about 3/52 weeks ago. The pain gradually increased to a constant state and began radiating to his throat. The pain is generally described as a sharp, stabbing, or aching sensation right near the sternum but sometimes feels like a dull ache in the throat when at rest. James noted that the pain escalated after an intense workout at the gym where he lifted heavy weights, emphasizing on bench pressing without a warm-up. He has a sedentary lifestyle punctuated by periods of intense physical activity a few times a week. He reports a history of rheumatoid arthritis but has not experienced a recent flare-up.

nprs.affected_area: sternal and upper chest region, exacerbated by movement and respiratory activities
dull ache in the throat, generally at rest or end of day

aggrevating_factors: lifting weights, particularly bench press, deep breathing, coughing, and twisting motion.
picture: [insert image of the front torso with particular emphasis on sternum radiating to the throat]
easing_factors: resting in a semi-reclined position, ice packs, and over-the-counter anti-inflammatory like Ibuprofen
past_history: history of rheumatoid arthritis; managed with medication and lifestyle. Had a significant episode of costochondritis five years ago.
medical_history: diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis seven years ago, regularly monitored and medicated.
medications: currently takes methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis, Ibuprofen prn for pain relief
personal_history: married with two young children. Leads a busy professional life, often falls into poor ergonomic postures. Social drinker and non-smoker. No family history of cardiac issues.
imaging: none to date, differential diagnosis suggests musculoskeletal origin given history and presentation
